data.text:
John Lennon

Profession: Musician and Beatle

Biography: Founding member of The Beatles, Lennon formed a songwriting partnership with Paul McCartney that became one of the most successful and famous in the history of music. Born in Liverpool, Lennon was in the group the Quarrymen which eventually developed into the Beatles in 1960.

As part of the best-selling group in music history, Lennon wrote or co-wrote many of the band's biggest hits. His rebellious nature gave his writings, interviews and work a notably acerbic and sardonic wit. After the group broke up in 1970, Lennon embarked on a successful solo career with his wife Yoko Ono. This included the hit 1971 single "Imagine".

His political activism, particularly in protesting against the Vietnam War, made him a controversial figure; the White House under Richard Nixon engaged in lengthy attempts to deport him.

In 1975 he withdrew from the music business to raise his son, Sean, but returned in 1980 to release the album Double Fantasy, with Yoko Ono. Three weeks after its release he was shot and killed by Mark David Chapman outside his Manhattan apartment. His death triggered an outpouring of grief on an unprecedented scale throughout the world.

Born: October 9, 1940

Birthplace: Liverpool, United Kingdom

Generation: Silent Generation

Chinese Zodiac: Dragon

Star Sign: Libra

Died: December 8, 1980 (aged 40)

Cause of Death: Murdered

Articles and Photos

Johann Sebastian Bach, The Pop Chart Wizard!

Celebrated for his choral and sacred music composed nearly 400 years ago, Johann Sebastian Bach has had surprising influence on modern pop charts.

Voice Of The Century – 'And Not Even Close'

Frank Sinatra cut his first disc on this day. It was a flop. But he would go on to be hailed as the “Voice of the Century”.

The Beatles? 'They have no future in show business'

In 1962, an unknown group called the Beatles travelled to London for a recording contract audition with one of the major record labels. They were rejected.

The Beatles on Ed Sullivan

The Beatles with TV host Ed Sullivan during their first appearance on his show in February 1964

Sgt Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band

One of the most famous album covers in music history, The Beatles' Sgt Pepper's Lonely Heart's Club Band, designed by artists Peter Blake and Jann Haworth

Memories of Elvis

Only one actor has appeared on film with both the Beatles and Elvis Presley: the little-known Norman Rossington.

Married Life

British "Beatles" musician John Lennon (21) weds British art school girlfriend Cynthia Powell (22); divorce in 1968

Cynthia Lennon sues Beatle member John Lennon for divorce on grounds of adultery

Cynthia Lennon is granted a divorce from The Beatles member John Lennon

British Beatle John Lennon (28) weds Japanese artist Yoko Ono (36) in Gibraltar, near Spain (his second marriage, her third), until his death in 1980

Historical Events

John Lennon (16) & Paul McCartney (15) meet for 1st time as Lennon's rock group Quarrymen perform at St. Peter's, Woolton's Parish Church in Liverpool, introduced by mutual friend Ivan Vaughn

Beatles perform as a trio, at Granada Cinema, in Bedford, England, as John Lennon is ill with a cold

John Lennon utters his famous quip at a Royal Variety Performance "For our last number, I'd like to ask your help. The people in the cheaper seats clap your hands? And for the rest of you, if you’ll just rattle your jewelry…" at the Prince of Wales Theatre in London

"In His Own Write", a book of short stories, poems and drawings by John Lennon is published

John Lennon is reunited with his father Freddie after 17 years

John Lennon's book of poetry and sketches "In His Own Write" is published in US

John Lennon passes his driving test

John Lennon's second book "A Spaniard in the Works" is published

John Lennon says "We (the Beatles) are more popular than Jesus"

Two Alabama radio hosts, Tommy Charles and Doug Layton of WAQY in Birmingham ask listeners to send in Beatles albums and merchandise to burn in response to John Lennon's anti-Jesus remark that "Christianity will go"

South African Broadcasting bans the playing of all Beatles songs due to John Lennon's remark that the band was "more popular than Jesus"

The Beatles hold press conference at the Astor Tower Hotel, in Chicago, Illinois; John Lennon apologizes for his "more popular than Jesus" remark

John Lennon meets Yoko Ono at an avante-garde art exposition at Indica Gallery in London

John Lennon takes delivery of his psychedelically painted Rolls Royce

The Rolling Stones release music single "We Love You", written by Mick Jagger and Keith Richard as a message of thanks to fans for their support after the duo's recent drug arrests; recording features backing vocals by John Lennon and Paul McCartney

"Yoko Plus Me" art exhibition by Yoko Ono opens in London (the "Me" is John Lennon)

Beatles George Harrison, John Lennon and their wives fly to India for transcendental meditation study with the Maharishi Mahesh Yogi

Paul McCartney & John Lennon appear on "The Tonight Show Starring Johnny Carson", to promote Apple Records, Joe Garagiola is substitute host

John Lennon and Yoko Ono plant two acorns for peace, at Coventry Cathedral, Conventry, England

John Lennon's 1st full art exhibition (You Are Here) opens at Robert Fraser Gallery in London

John Lennon sells his psychedelic painted Rolls-Royce

Private Eye magazine reports a John Lennon and Yoko Ono album will have a picture of them nude on the cover

Police find 219 grains of cannabis resin in John Lennon and Yoko Ono's apartment, they are fined £150 for marijuana possession

Yoko Ono announces she is having John Lennon's baby; she later suffers a miscarriage

John Lennon and Yoko Ono appear nude on cover of "Two Virgins" album

John Lennon is fined £150 for unauthorized drug possession

John Lennon and Yoko Ono release their 1st album "Two Virgins" in UK

Rolling Stones film TV show "Rock and Roll Circus"- guest performers include The Who, Jethro Tull, Taj Mahal, Marianne Faithfull, and John Lennon and Yoko Ono; the program never airs aired

John Lennon and Yoko Ono's "Two Virgins" album declared pornographic in New Jersey

Beatle John Lennon and new wife Yoko Ono stage their 1st bed-in for peace, at the Hilton Hotel in Amsterdam, Netherlands

John Lennon and Yoko Ono begin their 2nd bed-in for peace at Hotel La Reine Elizabeth, Montreal, Quebec, Canada

John Lennon and Yoko Ono record "Give Peace a Chance" in a Montreal hotel, during their second 'bed-in' for peace; other performers include Tommy Smothers, Petula Clark, Timothy Leary, and Dick Gregory

"The Ballad Of John & Yoko" by The Beatles hits #1 in UK; recording involved only John (guitars, vocals, percussion) and Paul (bass, drums, piano, backing voice)

John Lennon and Yoko Ono appear on David Frost's British TV Show

John Lennon and Yoko Ono are admitted to hospital after he crashes his car near Durness in the Scottish Highlands

"Give Peace a Chance" single by John Lennon & Plastic Ono Band is released in UK

Plastic Ono Band's 1st live performance, featuring John Lennon, Yoko Ono and Eric Clapton, at the Toronto Rock and Roll Revival festival

John Lennon privately announces to Paul and Ringo (George was not there) that he is leaving "The Beatles" at a London business meeting

John Lennon and Yoko Ono release their second album "Wedding Album" in UK

John Lennon returns MBE to protest "against Britain's involvement in the Nigeria-Biafra thing, against our support of America in Vietnam and against Cold Turkey slipping down the charts."

John Lennon and Yoko Ono's Plastic Ono Band, play their only European gig - appearing in UNICEF charity concert at London's Lyceum Ballroom, band is augmented by Bonnie & Delaney Bramlett, guitarists George Harrison and Eric Clapton, and keyboardist Billy Preston

Beatles last recording session at Abbey Road studios, completing George Harrison's tune "I Me Mine"; John Lennon was on vacation and did not participate

John Lennon and his wife Yoko Ono give a press conference in Aalborg, Denmark, revealing that they were only visiting

John Lennon pays £1,344 fines for 96 protesting South African rugby team playing in Scotland

John Lennon and Yoko Ono release hoax they are having dual sex change operations

John Lennon meets Yoko Ono's parents in Japan

John Lennon and Plastic Ono Band record "Power to the People" at his Ascot Sound home studio at Tittenhurst Park, England

South African Broadcasting Corp lifts its ban on the Beatles, begun after John Lennon's infamous "Jesus" quote in 1966

John Lennon records the song "Imagine" at his Ascot Sound home studio at Tittenhurst Park, England

John Lennon and Yoko Ono appear for an unannounced performance, joining Frank Zappa on stage at Fillmore East in NYC

Beatle John Lennon leaves England for the final time, moving to New York City

John Lennon and Yoko Ono appear on Dick Cavett Show (ABC-TV)

Apple Records releases John Lennon's second solo studio album, "Imagine" in US; it tops the charts in US, UK, Australia, and 3 other countries

John Lennon releases his megahit single "Imagine"

Apple Records releases John Lennon's second solo studio album, "Imagine" in UK; it tops the charts in US, UK, Australia, and 3 other countries

John Lennon and Yoko Ono appear on "Dick Cavett Show"

John Lennon and Yoko Ono record the single "Happy Xmas (War is Over)" in NYC

John Lennon and Yoko Ono release single "Happy Xmas (War is Over)" in the US

US Senator Strom Thurmond suggests John Lennon be deported

John Lennon and Yoko Ono co-host the syndicated TV show "The Mike Douglas Show" for an entire week, in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania

American guitar legend Chuck Berry and former Beatle John Lennon perform together, with Yoko Ono, on 'The Mike Douglas Show' TV program

John Lennon and Yoko Ono end a week of co-hosting the syndicated "The Mike Douglas Show", in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania

John Lennon and Yoko Ono are served with deportation papers by US Immigration Department

NYC Mayor John Lindsey appeals that John Lennon not be deported

John Lennon says his phone is tapped by FBI on "The Dick Cavett Show"

Apple Records releases John Lennon and Yoko Ono's political album "Sometime in NYC" in US; includes studio recordings of songs "Woman is the Nigger of the World", "Attica State" and "Luck of the Irish"; and some live tracks from 1971 concert with Frank Zappa

John Lennon and Yoko Ono's "One on One" benefit shows (matinee and evening) for children at Madison Square Garden, New York, his final full concert performance

John Lennon and Yoko Ono perform three songs ("Imagine"; "Now Or Never"; "Give Peace A Chance") on Jerry Lewis' 7th Muscular Dystrophy telethon at the Americana Hotel, NYC

Apple Records releases John Lennon and Yoko Ono's political album "Sometime in NYC" in UK, delayed by publishing rights dispute; includes some live tracks from 1971 concert with Frank Zappa

John Lennon and Yoko Ono form a new country with no laws or boundaries, called Nutopia, its national anthem is silence

John Lennon sues US government to admit FBI is tapping his phone, they deny doing so

Apple Records releases John Lennon's fourth studio album, "Mind Games" in US

Apple Records releases John Lennon's fourth studio album, "Mind Games" in UK

John Lennon is (again) ordered to leave US in 60 days, due to a 1968 marijuana charge in the UK (he doesn't)

RCA records releases "Pussy Cats", the tenth album by American singer Harry Nilsson in the US; album was produced by John Lennon and Nilsson worked through a serious vocal chord injury which diminished his vaunted range

John Lennon reports seeing a UFO in NYC

John Lennon's single "Whatever Gets You Thru the Night", featuring Elton John, released in US; it was Lennon's only solo No. 1 single during his lifetime

Apple Records releases John Lennon's fifth studio album, "Walls & Bridges" in US; features No. 1 single "Whatever Gets You Through the Night" (with Elton John) and "#9 Dream"

John Lennon appears as guest DJ on WNEW-FM (NYC)

Apple Records releases John Lennon's fifth studio album, "Walls & Bridges" in UK; features No. 1 single "Whatever Gets You Through the Night" (with Elton John) and "#9 Dream"

John Lennon's single "Whatever Gets You Through the Night", featuring Elton John, goes to #1 in US; the last of the Beatles with a solo chart-topper, it was the only one during his lifetime

John Lennon's last concert appearance, as a guest of Elton John, Madison Square Garden, New York City NYC; they perform "Whatever Gets You Thru the Night"; "Lucy In The Sky With Diamonds"; and "I Saw Her Standing There"

John Lennon releases single "#9 Dream"

A&M Records releases John Lennon's sixth studio album, "Rock 'n' Roll" album, cover songs of early rock numbers

RCA releases "Young Americans", David Bowie's 9th studio album, recorded in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, and New York City; featuring appearances by John Lennon on two tracks, it peaks in the U.S. charts at No. 9, and No. 2 in the U.K.

John Lennon releases single "Stand By Me", a cover of Ben E. King's song from 1961

John Lennon gives what becomes his final public performance at a gala salute to British media mogul Lew Grade at the Grand Ballroom of the Hilton Hotel, NYC; he performed 3 songs - Little Richard’s “Slippin’ and Slidin’”, Ben E. King’s “Stand By Me”, and closed with his own “Imagine”

Ringo Starr appears on "The Smothers Brothers Show", singing Hoyt Axton's "No No Song", and John Lennon is the guest on Tom Snyder's "Tomorrow" program, in what turns out to be his final television interview; both on NBC-TV

RCA releases David Bowie single "Fame", with cameo appearance by John Lennon

US decides John Lennon won't be deported due to UK pot conviction

Former Beatle John Lennon is granted a green card for permanent residence in US

John Lennon and Yoko Ono begin recording sessions for their "Double Fantasy" album at the Hit Factory, NYC

John Lennon and Yoko Ono sign a recording contract with Geffen Records

John Lennon releases single "(Just Like) Starting Over" in UK

Geffen Records releases John Lennon and Yoko Ono's album "Double Fantasy"

John Lennon and Yoko Ono pose nude for photographer Allan Tannenbaum

Annie Leibovitz has a photo-shoot with John Lennon, the last person to professionally photograph him before he is murdered on the same day

At 2 PM EST there is 10 minutes of silence in memory of John Lennon

John Lennon's single "Woman" is posthumously released in the UK

Beatles George Harrison & Paul McCartney record vocals to a Ringo Starr track written by George, and re-worked as a tribute to John Lennon - "All Those Years Ago"

John Lennon's single "Watching the Wheels" released posthumously in UK

George Harrison releases single "All Those Years Ago" in UK: the song was a tribute to John Lennon, and featured Ringo Starr on drums, and Paul and Linda McCartney on backing vocals

George Harrison releases "Somewhere in England", his ninth studio album, includes John Lennon tribute "All Those Years Ago" (Featuring Paul and Ringo)

Mark David Chapman pleads guilty to killing former Beatle John Lennon

Mark David Chapman is sentenced to 20 yrs to life for John Lennon's murder

WABC radio (NYC) plays its last record - John Lennon's "Imagine" - and switches to all-talk format

John Lennon single "Nobody Told Me" released posthumously

Geffen Records releases "Milk & Honey" album by John Lennon and Yoko Ono, featuring un-released recordings made during the 1980 "Double Fantasy" sessions, including "Grow Old With Me"

John Lennon single "Borrowed Time" released posthumously

Part of Central Park in New York City is named "Strawberry Fields" honoring John Lennon

John Lennon's single "I'm Stepping Out" released posthumously

John Lennon's 'Every Man has a Woman Who Loves Him' released posthumously

"Strawberry Fields" memorial to John Lennon in Central Park, NYC is dedicated by mayor Ed Koch

"John Lennon: Live in NYC" album is released posthumously

John Lennon's "Menlove Avenue" album released posthumously

Radio stations around world play "Imagine" honoring John Lennon on what would have been his 50th birthday

9th Rock and Roll Hall of Fame inductees: The Animals; The Band; Duane Eddy; The Grateful Dead; Elton John; John Lennon; Bob Marley; Rod Stewart; Willie Dixon; and Johnny Otis

Beatles release single, a cover of Shirelles song, "Baby It's You" (written by Burt Bacharach & Mack David), with late John Lennon as lead singer; 1st Fab Four single in nearly 10 years

Apple Records releases The Beatles "Anthology 1" (double CD/triple LP), the first of a 3-part series of rare recordings and outtakes by the Beatles; set covers the years 1955-64, as well as new collaboration "Free as a Bird" - a John Lennon demo augmented by additional lyrics and performances by the surviving three; album tops Billboard chart in US and peaks at no. 2 in UK

Apple Records releases The Beatles "Anthology 2" (double CD/triple LP)", the second of 3-part series of rare recordings and outtakes by the Beatles; set covers the years 1965-68, as well as new collaboration "Real Love" - a John Lennon demo augmented by additional lyrics and performances by the surviving three; album tops record charts in US and UK

4-inch lock of John Lennon's hair sells for $35,000 to a memorabilia collector at an auction in Dallas, Texas

Apple Records release the last Beatles song "Now and Then" as a double A-sided single, backed with their first "From Me To You"; the new song was built from an unfinished 1978 John Lennon demo and 1995 attempt to complete it that had been abandoned due to technical issues, resolved by new technology

Quotes by John Lennon

"Imagine all the people living life in peace. You may say I'm a dreamer, but I'm not the only one." - Dreams, Peace

"Love, Love, Love. All you need is love. Love is all you need." - Love
